title: Do some doctors regret becoming doctors? Why? How common is this? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know a family who are nearly all M.D.s. The father was a physician, and 6 of his 7 children are too. About two years ago, my family was dining with this family when we started to discuss the medical field (at the time I wanted to become a Physician Assistant). To our shock, all 6 physicians agreed they would not pursue an M.D. if they had to do it over again. They felt it simply wasn’t worth it. Now, these were all successful, established, and respected physicians, not some embittered burnouts. They provided good reasoning to back their statement: The Education: training to become a Physician will consume a solid 8 years of your youth, with very little time left over for anything else. The coursework and workload are the most difficult of any educational path you could possibly choose, besides maybe high level math or science research. The cost of this education can rise into the hundreds of thousands of dollars, meaning most doctors graduate with massive debt. In addition, med school admissions have become increasingly competitive. Only students with perfect grades, extra curriculars, and a +95% MCAT will be accepted to the really prestigious schools. An “average” medical student (still a Valedictorian by most standards) might end up spending 4 years at a C-grade school in rural Iowa, if they’re lucky. And without the credential of a “good” med school to your name, your career is already extremely limited. I knew an excellent student with near perfect grades, who spent a solid two years after college applying to every medical school she could find. Not one accepted her. It’s just that competitive. Don’t even try unless you know youre smart enough to ace high level chemistry classes all day long. If you drop out of med school, you are fucked. You get all the debt with no earning power, and your reputation is ruined.Residency: you thought med school was the hard part, huh? Well, after you graduate, expect to spend 3–4 years as a resident doctor in training, which by many accounts is the worst part of the whole process. There is basically no limit to how many hours residents can work, or for how little pay. Senior Physicians are often verbally abusive, and will dump excessive grunt work on you. You’re expected to perform the tasks of a full doctor, but with none of the perks. Limits actually were imposed on resident hours after the high profile death of a patient in the 1980s due to a mistake caused by sleep deprivation. The limits they imposed? No more than 24 consecutive hours, and no more than 80 hours total per week. Yeah, that’s the “limit”. Luckily, by this point you’re used to extreme sleep deprivation and never getting laid.The Pay: What’s wrong with this part? Doctors make great money, right? Well, kind of. Doctors make low to mid 6 figure, usually 120k-300k per year for general practitioners. High level surgeons and specialist can make 300–500k, but thats around the upper limit. It’s good money, sure - but you could make as much or more as a corporate lawyer, and law school is 3 years to medical school/residency’s 8. Same goes for a Masters in business or finance - or you could pour the time, effort, and capital from your education into starting a business or investment fund, which could be even more profitable in the long term. So doctors are actually paid very little compared to the training they receive, and the intelligence and work ethic they bring to the table. And let’s not forget that educational debt! Even at 200k, you’ll be paying off that interest for years. And with the recurring costs of certification, filing fees, and continuing ed, you may never feel truly wealthy.Job Satisfaction: Becoming a Physician is hard - really hard. Medical school is basically rings 6–9 in Dante’s inferno. But everyone knows this, and students go into the field with some idea of the challenges that lie ahead. So even with all the work, and sleeplessness, and expense, it’s worth it in the end because Doctors save lives, right? What could possibly be more gratifying that? Well, as Bob Dylan says, “the times, they are a changing”. The new practices of the HMO run medical industry are slowly but surely squeezing the joy out of the Physician’s profession. For example, many healthcare systems have truly idiotic requirements for physicians to sign off on nearly everything their underlings do. In California, an RN can’t even start an IV without a Physician’s approval. Now, nurses are master phlebotomists. They could start an IV drunk and blindfolded on the deck of the Titanic. But somehow, an MD must come by to sign off every single time they do it, or risk major trouble. When I volunteered at a hospital, I witnessed physicians running from place to place all day long, just signing off on stuff. They didn’t get to do procedures. They didn’t get to talk with patients. It was mainly the nurses doing these things, while the MDs used their 8 years of education to run around checking boxes. It was actually very very sad, but at least they were getting good exercise.In summary, I cannot recommend the Physician’s path to anyone. It is simply too hard, too expensive, and has a lame payoff at the end. Luckily, there are plenty of more reasonable career paths available in the medical field. You can become a Physician Assistant or Nurse Practitioner with only a Masters degree - you don’t even need a Biochem B.S. or anything, just a handful of prerequisites. There are masters degrees for Anesthesiology and MRI operation as well. All these jobs pay 6 figures. Nursing school is a good investment too, although very competitive now. However, any of these would be preferable to the barefoot trail of broken glass and Legos that is the road to becoming a Physician.

Hello there Quora :) I am very happy this question was asked because it gives an opportunity to share a different perspective of the current situation as a student who just graduated from medical school. **DISCLAIMER: This is my personal perspective. I do not think this represents all doctors and as you can see from the other numerous answers there are perfectly content docs out there. So please don’t take any offense these are just things I have been observing and also heard feedback about from my peers who were in medical school at the same time and at different institutions. Thanks :)** One of my biggest regrets is going to medical school IN THE CURRENT AGE. There’s a lot of things that medical school doesn’t prepare you for and a lot of things that are old and not changing about the system. If I could go back I wouldn’t do it again CURRENTLY. I stress these words over and over because I think that medicine is slowly changing (very slowly), but it is changing for the better as more awareness is raised. So what didn’t I like about medical school? Three main things for me personally: Medical school and doctor training is currently very very abusive in it’s teaching style.One of the first things that a lot of medical schools will tell you (and I think a lot of people who went to medical school will agree with me) on your first day is “Welcome to medical school, you will now be learning like you are drinking from a fire hose.” To me as someone who has been teaching and mentoring since high school, this message just basically sounds like “Hey, we know this is too much information, but we are going to give it to you all in too little time anyways so good luck and those of you who can’t make it just aren’t cut out for this.” There is a sad term called a “Gunner” that gets floated around in medical school. I’m not sure if this is a term that is used in other fields, but particularly in medicine this is someone who achieves the best grades and scores no matter the cost. Your class mate is struggling? Good riddance. That means I look better. Your team member has that doctor who is mean to all their students? Look away and be happy cause that isn’t you. This is the essence of a gunner. A lot of people will joke around and call people gunners, but the way that the current medical system is set up we are rewarding and breeding for gunners. After the first 2 years (1 and a half years at some schools) of medical school students will leave the classroom and go directly into the hospitals for clinical learning. This is when the training style for Gunners runs rampant. Grading tends to not be objective during this time and because it is based on the opinion of the teaching physician all of the medical students compete with each other to try and impress them. Hence why gunners run rampant and are rewarded for their behavior. This kind of environment fosters medical students no longer asking questions, going home to memorize as much as they can to look impressive, not helping each other as much as they should, and overall creating an environment where future doctors are hyper competitive with each other instead of helping each other. In the United States doctors don’t have unions and are forced to work 80 hour weeks which is the maximum that was placed in recent years because studies were showing that the sleep deprivation was harming patients. Prior to this it was even higher hence the term “resident physicians.” This means that you work 12 hours (usually getting into the hospital at 5am and staying until 5pm minimum) 6–7 days a week. The golden rule of vacation for doctors is “4 days off a month” during their training years so that means you can actually work 26–27 days STRAIGHT before you have even 1 day off working those 12 hour minimum shifts (this does not include times to respond to patient emails online, time to finish patient notes, travel time to work, or even time to get ready the next day). I have heard old school doctors complaining about the implementation of such a rule because “We did it so why shouldn’t you.” Funny part is many hospitals “enforce” this rule by sending residents home, but they are reminded that all patient notes need to be finished before the next day so in reality you aren’t free from work at all and that 80 hour work week is really much higher. You just now get to do it at home, and this is seen as “generous.” Everyone goes in saying that they will never become the monsters that they were taught by, that they will never be that gunner, but after going through such an abusive system many people change and don’t even realize it, I mean who can blame them? Think about this, you work 12 hours a day, should get 8 hours of sleep…that leaves you 4 hours left in the day. 4 hours to be with your family, your significant other, your children, and your own physical and mental health. That is also assuming that you live right next to the hospital and get home immediately. Forget even having dinner, showering, or other personal hygiene rituals. This is from personal experience as well as from the numerous friends and family members that I have personally witnessed transform (in good and bad ways, but when talking about the bad ways most dismiss it and don’t believe it. Which makes sense…who wants to hear they are changing for the worse? This includes myself as well, and I am currently trying my best to change that!)*Update* Recently a doctor from South Africa was brave enough to put her recordings and interactions in her residency training online seen below. If you don’t have time to view the video the summary is this **there is a female doctor in training who ended up leaving medical training because she was being told demeaning and sexist things. Upon bringing it up to her superiors instead of being listened to she was told that she was over-reacting and that she is being the resident and person “no one wants to be.” They told her she would never get a job again if she continued pursuing these things.** I would like to say that this is rare, but unfortunately the truth is it is not as rare as you would think. It’s not just happening to women either. This abusive style permeates through all genders, races, beliefs, etc. It’s a MEDICAL CULTURE. Which is really sad for such an altruistic field. All in all right now things are being taught with a “hazing” type of mentality where people just say “Well I went through this hell…so why shouldn’t you?” instead of trying to continue to improve it for subsequent generations. Now to be clear…this is NOT all doctors, this is NOT all programs, but there’s a lot of them out there for various reasons and the only way things are going to change are by raising awareness and working together. 2. There’s so much that we need to do to change the medical system, yet medical schools are only teaching us how to be doctors in hospitals only. We don’t learn any entrepreneurship skills even though some of us are expected to run clinics and hospitals in the future. We aren’t required to learn anything in regards to health policy even though doctors are more needed on Capitol Hill. Heck, we don’t even learn how to maintain our own bodily health and mental sanity. (If you are interested in reading more about what I think is lacking in medical education you can read what I have written here: Tanakorn Kittisarapong's answer to What useful skills do they not teach you in medical school?) There was an interesting survey done by a website called Med Page Today which keeps up with the latest medical news and trends which basically asked doctors: Are You Thinking About Quitting Medicine? (you can click the question to go to the survey there). A staggering 61% answered “Yes” with over 550 votes. Of course this is an online anonymous survey, so there could be many biases, but it is interesting to note how many people responded yes and that the age range was actually pretty evenly distributed (meaning it wasn’t just young docs, middle aged docs, or older docs it was a nice spread among all of them). Physician has also become one of the professions (if not the top profession) with the highest suicidal rate. It’s estimated 300–400 physicians commit suicide EACH YEAR. That is one doctor dying in a totally preventable way EVERY DAY.Highest Suicide Rate by Profession Physician Burnout Rates Top 50 Percent (And That's Not the Worst Finding) Medical student suicide: It's impact is devastating. This case proves it., petition: Stop the suicide epidemic in medical schools and residency programs! 3. We are opening more medical schools, but the RESIDENCY (doctors in training) positions are not growing as quickly. The interesting incoming doctor shortage that the American Association of Medical Colleges (AAMC) has done studies on in 2016 estimating a shortage of 61,700-94,700 physicians by 2025. (If you are interested look here: GME Funding and Physician Workforce). In response to this numerous medical schools have been opened up in order to prepare for this upcoming shortage, makes logical sense. Now comes the issue I mentioned at the start. Take a look at this image:   Notice the number of applicants went up by 1,036, but the number of positions went up by a little more than half of that only at 538 (even the number that are “active” and submitted preferences, meaning they went to interviews and submitted which hospitals they wanted to go to {people such as myself}, went up by a higher number of 571). Active Seniors 18,187 up from last year. Matched Seniors 17,057 up from last year. % Positions filled by Seniors 61.2% DOWN from last year. Also take notice that the number of active seniors went up 162, but the number of matched seniors went up 125. That’s 37 seniors lacking in matching. Critics will say that there are numerous factors for this, and I whole-heartedly agree, but where the heck are these seniors going? In addition isn’t it worrisome that there are 1,130 UNMATCHED seniors??? This is only U.S. graduates, not even including those from Doctors of Osteopathic Medical Schools, U.S. citizens trying to come home from Carribbean Schools, and International Medical Graduates. For which the numbers are worse for and can hover down to 40–50%. Now what are these seniors suppose to do in the mean time or if they want to do something related to medicine but not be a clinical physician? Unfortunately having an M.D. degree doesn’t qualify you for a wide range of jobs that something like an M.B.A might qualify you for. At least not that I am aware of (I would love for someone with insight to comment on this), but from personal experience myself it is hard to figure out what jobs I can get with an M.D. degree solely because my education has only trained me to be a doctor. There is so much talent wasted, and there is so much about the healthcare field that needs to be fixed that I am shocked there isn’t more education and resources to get these graduates to other jobs/opportunities that can help the healthcare field in general. I am saying this after I spoke to 12 different physicians at my institution who could not advise me on what I could do with just an M.D. degree other than go to residency AND after going to my schools career center. Scary and disheartening if I do say so myself. It costs so much money to apply. I spent easily over $10,000 on applications and interviews because not only do you have to pay for each application you send in, but you also have to fly to each location for an interview as well as hotel.And let me just end with being a little honest about my situation. I didn’t get into residency after applying to over 50 programs (for those curious, I applied to Pediatrics which is considered a “non-competitive” specialty. I personally don’t like that term, but it’s what is being used right now). This was after I followed the advise of all my advisers. I didn’t pass Step 1 the first time, but that was my only hiccup in the entirety of medical school. No other failures, no other red flags. In fact I ran multiple organizations at my school, did research that got published, and even created a peer teaching program that ran for a while. Problem is that in a system where the number of applicants to residency positions greatly exceeds the spots, the quickest way to weed people out is to look at the score and that red flag was enough to brand me. I don’t even blame them, I understand how stressful it is to weed out thousands of applications (I have had jobs in the past where I was responsible for interviewing and hiring as well as interviewed numerous prospective students while I was in medical school). It’s just an unfortunate reality of the current situation we are in with the system right now. The weird thing is that you can’t even retake the Step exams in order to get higher scores. Once you pass you are stuck with that score for at least 7 years when the score expires. So in other words for 7 years you can’t improve your chances to get into residency by SCORE (there are other things that one can do such as continued education, research, volunteering, maybe working for a well known doctor, etc.), which is interesting because there is such a heavy weight on score in this field. Now I hope this didn’t sound bitter, but just a reality that I personally faced. With $350,000 of debt and over 10 years of my life spent on getting into medical school and graduating it was shocking that no one could advise me on what I could do with my M.D. degree to earn money to begin paying down my debt while waiting another year to apply to residency and needing to spend another $10,000. Everyone keeps saying “do research”, but unfortunately I have worked on research projects in the past and those don’t usually pay due to the uncertainty of grants. Or the jobs that do pay get taken by more qualified Ph.D’s or Masters degree holders who have much more experience in the lab. I come from a middle class background, so I can’t rely on my soon-to-retire parents to pay off my debt. I can’t even imagine how someone from with a background with even less money can cope with the situation. It doesn’t shock me to hear that there are doctors out there working as waiters and coffee baristas. My whole point of this post was to raise awareness that there are THOUSANDS of people graduating from medical schools and CAN’T CONTINUE TRAINING. Even after enduring years of debt, education, and abusive teaching styles. I hope that people on Quora read this and share and spread more awareness because this is a really large issue that needs to be addressed and I myself am really adamantly pursuing individuals and work that is making this change happen. Thank you for your time. And as always, thank you so much for reading. I love discussions (as long as they are constructive and friendly) so please don’t hesitate to comment :)

Probably more common than you might think. In an answer to a question about terrible things done to me my answer was ‘med school which turned a man into a surgeon’. It’s that hard, that intense and, to some, too deeply into to quit, to committed to do anything else. I started in a class of 31 men on a Neurosurgical path; 7 of us finished. My admiration goes to those people who realize this wasn’t the choice they thought it was and withdraw. Too many young people proclaim their desire to be a doctor of some form and do so for too long. Eventually it’s just assumed that’s what they’ll do so, in a sense, they’re stuck in their own mouth trap. Now it’s off, eventually, to med school. They do well enough, graduate, perhaps start a practice but their professional reputation reflects what is their genuine disinterest in what they’re doing. By now there’s a great deal of money at stake and, since families, who’ve been around and heard of their desperation to be a doctor, may well have gone into serious debt to see their child accommodated. The guilt of concurrently hating what you do but seeing responsibilities can be crushing. Please do not misunderstand me, if you want to be a doctor, great, hope you’ll make it and be a good one but….if you have doubts that linger through maybe the second year (Everyone entering med school has doubts at first-it’s that killing.) possibly you need to speak to someone at the school and discuss it with them. And I put it that way for I’ve seen many people slightly shift their interest to something that will attract their interest, keep them involved and keep them in medicine. Briefly I had a GP whom I hated. The reason? You may have heard of ‘bedside manner’? He couldn’t even get to cryptside manner. What he should of done, and finally did, was medical research. That’s what I mean about shifting in the general field of medicine but finding a more satisfying path. Why did I become a surgeon? I can tell you to the date and the hour. 11:40 am, August 11, 1965. I was shot on the first day of the Watts Riots on the campus of USC from which I was receiving my Ph.D. in Physics. My Godfather, and my parents, decided I’d had enough of California so sent me off to him in Cape Town to go to Med School. Which I did. What none of us could have known was that although I would do well and loved my field, I would be diagnosed with MS, not a disease for surgeons….(oh, how the hour? That was on the chart at the emergency room at Good Samaritan where, surprisingly, somewhat over a decade later, I would be on staff.) Later I happened to continue thinking about this question and realized something. Many of the doctors who were ‘reluctant’ physicians all came from a line of doctors. To them, they were pre-ordained to attend med school, become a doctor. In the instance I cite, the doctor who had no ‘cryptside’ manner, both his father and grandfather were physicians. This isn’t always the case, certainly, my Oncologist is the son of another Oncologist and he’s a brilliant doctor, but the instance in which it does happen is sufficient to be worthy of note.

I don’t regret it. Here’s what I tell my students and anyone looking at going into medicine: In ANY job you do, there will be a mountain of nonsense. Nonsense is a ubiquitous substance in any job worth doing and this is just a fact of life: *Cops/Firefighters/EMS do so much paperwork that they have to carry two pens so that if one runs out they have a spare. *Lawyers do paperwork for a living. *Pilots have to keep logbooks, learn procedures, go through manuals, etc. etc. etc. *Scientists get to actually do science during their degrees and postdoctoral fellowships. By the time they get to the point of being principal investigators, I noticed in college how mine were always in their offices writing or reviewing. Their days of doing actual science were over. *Executive chefs spend more time in the office than in the kitchen. Ask Jamie Oliver or Gordan Ramsay how much of their typical days they actually get to spend cooking. So what matters is: when you AREN’T doing the nonsense, are you enjoying what you do? For me, when I’m not writing notes and answering phone messages and filling out forms and doing stupid trainings and sitting in meetings, I am seeing patients. And that is the bit I live for. Calming the anxious mother worried that her smiling, happy baby with a cough might have a pneumonia. Breaking a huffing, puffing, wheezing kid out of an asthma attack. Suturing a wound. This is the stuff that makes my job great. Oh, and at least at my company we have very collegial relations with our management (in fact, I’m part of the physician leadership team) and, while I’ve chosen the field in medicine that is lowest-paid and hardest-working (General Pediatrics), my income still puts me in the top 5–10% of the nation and I live quite comfortably, if not opulently. This is, in fact, my dream job and I’m actually doing it. So if you get hung up on the nonsense you’re going to hate any job you do. If you focus on the fun part of the job (your patients), you’ll love your career as a physician. And if you don’t like patients, then either go into radiology or pathology -OR- don’t go to medical school. For me, if my life were rewound to age 20 and I got to keep the knowledge I have, I’d let it roll forward just as it did on the first go-around.

In a recent poll 1 out of every 5 physicians regretted their choice. I don't.In recent years Dutch doctors are given an overall country-wide budget by a government agency within which all care must be carried out, if one oversteps the budget the money has to be paid back. This has triggered some big lawsuits.The autonomous growth of the costs of medical care is not of our making, patients want all the newest technology for themselves and their loved ones, irrespective if it is applicable to them or not, since they think they have medical expertise from reading about miracle drugs and miracle cures in the tabloids, they claim it is their right since they have paid for their medical insurance policies, while everybody knows we have to equally share the medical care the country can afford. A lot of people who think they know a lot are in fact badly educated, and blinded by fear and emotion are often unwilling to listen to a reasonable explanation why they don't need an expensive new fangled exam "just to make sure.” But new effective drugs are in reality much more expensive, think of anti-cancer drugs, treatments are more and more complex and expensive, think of intensive care medicine (I once was an intensivist physician). So apart from unfounded claims, up to date bonafide treatment is costing us more and more. Add to that the fact that we all live longer, so will need more medical care during our lifespan. That fuels the growth of medical expenditure. In real life, whom to choose, the young mother with young children and incurable very aggressive breast cancer, in whom costly meds will buy her two more months for her to put her affairs in order and say goodbye to her children, or the young previously healthy person grievously sick after a serious accident for which he bears no blame, who has the potential to survive and live a long productive life afterwards? I don't have the answer. At present we still can treat both. In The Netherlands the medical profession is quickly being feminized, at present 80% or more of the medical graduates are female, of whom most will later work part time, some will not practice at all, which is why the planners think we will need a lot more doctors than will be graduating in the coming years; a lot of older male doctors like me who worked full time have retired or will be retiring soon. A female specialist once summed it up like this: lost of income, lost of status, lost of autonomy, that is why few males now choose to become a physician. Add to this the often long and tiring hours working hard bearing a lot of responsibility even when still at a younger age, which is hard on your partner, your children and yourself;, I would therefore not recommend just anybody to choose this profession, only if they really want to and know why they want to and understand the consequences for their life should they choose this profession. In The Netherlands after graduating from high school at 18, one must do med school (3 years for Bachelor, 3 years for Master, including 3 years of unpaid internship), after which one must apply for another 3 to 6 years of (paid) training as a resident before being able to start a career (at between 30 and 35 years old) and maybe a family. Perfect child care arrangements are paramount to having a happy life if you're female and a doctor, since a lot of female doctors with children feel inadequate both as a mother and as a doctor. A supportive partner is a must, a flexible partner is a blessing. While in The Netherlands in general 1 in every 3 relationships fail, in the medical profession it is 1 in 2. This is a fact little known to lay people, medical doctors are generally viewed as a desirable partner. Having said that, after 40 years it is still the most interesting, satisfying and gratifying profession I know; it makes me feel I am doing something worthwhile, but I know I only could do my work properly because of the staunch support of my wife. My children didn't know better so didn't suffer. My daughter eventually choose to become a doctor herself, she is now a PhD student, and is very happy being a doctor, hoping for a residency after attaining her PhD. Also in these difficult times, being a doctor practically guarantees you a job as long as you are not picky, just like nurses, IT people and maybe engineers. So all you people who are thinking about doing med school, think again, and if you're still convinced it is the profession for you, and think you know why, go ahead, invest a lot in your future and have a fulfilling professional live, but keep in mind you will need a supportive partner or either your relationship or your career will fail. EDIT:In 2013 the job prospect for physicians and surgeons in The Netherlands has gone bad, as many as 50 young certified highly trained surgeons at present aren't able to find a real job, so either do a locum, or work for free so not to lose their dexterity and license to practice. Clinical geneticist are losing their tenure, since they only work in academic hospitals and these had had big cuts in their budgets. The same for nurses.We still have some waiting lists, but budget cuts won't allow us to hire more young professionals, medical associations are calling on older docs to work less hours a week and so make room for younger docs to have a paid job. EDIT 2015:At present jobs in the health sector are scarce, 670 docs are registered as having no paid job, 158 of them highly trained medical specialists, the bulk are basic docs who after graduating med school haven't done further training e.g. residency (can't get into one). We don't know how many out of desperation has left the profession, and those having temp jobs. Our MD daughter has decided to forgo clinical medicine altogether after attaining her PhD in clinical genetics this summer, going for 100% clinical research, meaning hopping from one project to the next where they still have the money to do the research, no job security at all. EDIT 2016:Our daughter has left medicine altogether due an almost burn out, the research environment in the top medical institute she worked at was even worse than for those doing clinical work, the boss demanding that she worked during her daily 2x90 minute commute to and from work, and Saturday mornings too; she has today August 15th 2016 started a new career as a Data Analyst trying to build a bridge between clinical medicine and ICT, analyzing what clinicians want from the ICT people and rephrasing that in terms ICT people understand and can work with. Being among lots of nerds (brother although being in a marketing position is a nerd, longtime spouse is a programmer, many of their friends and acquaintances are programmers too), the firm will provide her with some course/training for that.

People love the career of a physician for many reasons; people regret, or burn out on, the career for many reasons. There is no one answer. Being a physician in most cases involves an intimate relationship with human dysfunction and human suffering. Treating a schizophrenic who refuses to take medications and is brought in screaming and threatening, guiding a patient and family through a death from painful and incurable cancer, watching the decline of a diabetic hypertensive heart failure patient who cannot afford their medicines. Or would rather spend their money on methaphetamines and alcohol: the life of a doctor is not serenely dispensing bolts of medical wisdom and sure fire cures in a spotless white coat. If it doesn't hurt, you’re not doing it right. If people get into medicine without understanding how central human suffering will be to their working life, or if it impacts them too much, they may regret becoming a physician. Physicians make a fairly good income in the United States; those that think they would have made a lot more in another line of work are mostly kidding themselves. I don’t think physicians entertain the fantasy of making their fortunes elsewhere because of greed or ambition; I think physicians who are burned out for other reasons and are determined to see nothing good about their profession, including their income, engage in a “grass is greener” fallacy. Some people also regret becoming physicians because the pressures of the job have increased while the respect accorded the position has declined. In the “bad old days” physicians were expected to work brutal hours and be available to their patients day and night. In return they were positioned at the top of a very rigid hierarchy, and received deference from patients, nurses, administratours and the public. Today all organizations are “flatter” and more rule-driven than they were 50 years ago, including hospitals and clinics. (This is mostly a good thing, in medicine, but it has unintended effects too.) The physician is still expected to take ultimate responsibility for the patient and their care, we are still legally responsible when things go wrong, but rather than being “kings and queens of the castle,” we are under pressure from all directions: expected to work faster (always faster,) cheaper, more successfully, according to standards and practices laid out by CMS, JHACO, the hospital and the practice. Patient satisfaction, nursing satisfaction, lab tech and pharmacist satisfaction . . . If you can imagine being in a workplace where failure to organize an “A+” effort by the team can literally kill people, where you are expected to work faster and faster every year, with no mistakes or deviations from sometimes irrational or ill-conceived guidelines (such as the enforced introduction of poor-designed electronic medical records and electronic orders which add literally hours in front of the computer each day) from multiple different authorities, all while making every member of the team feel valuable and listened to, without ever scowling or raising your voice, and you will understand the tremendous pressure that leads some physicians to burn out.

Heck yeah, some doctors regret becoming physicians. When I was working for a pediatrician in a state agency, I made the decision to go back to school to become an occupational therapist (I was already an RN). I expected her to be happy for me but she seemed…jealous??? “Well,” she frowned, “it would be nice to do something else, but once you spend all that money on med school, it just doesn't seem worth it.” Another time, I overheard three (female) pediatricians (who rotated as hospitalists on the hospital's pediatric floors) discussing how if they had it to do over again, they would be nurse practitioners, not physicians. They didn't think the difference in salary made up for their crazy work schedules. Once upon a time, a physician could expect a thriving private practice and tremendous prestige and community respect when he/she graduated from med school, along with a rewarding income. These days, medicine has become corporate and the majority of physicians are employees of large corporations that have a primary focus on the bottom line, not on quality of care. This is an issue with not-for-profits as well as for-profits. Also consider that physicians graduate with an average student loan debt of over $200,000 according to Google. It's an enormous burden. Recently, eight anonymous physicians at UF Health Shands Hospital gave an interview in which they described retaliation from their Pediatric Department Chairman when staff doctors brought up quality of care issues at the Children's Hospital and Clinics. The chair of the Department (Scott Rivkees, who is now also the Surgeon General of the state of Florida in addition to remaining Chair of the department of Pediatrics at UFHealth)also has privately sued a physician he fired at UFHealth for “slander and libel"; the sued physician detailed the kinds of retaliation physicians endure in his deposition, included firings, demotions, salary cuts, and bogus referrals to Florida's Professionals Resource Network for “mental health issues" or “addiction treatment.” References: look up Scott Rivkees in the (free) Alachua County Florida Public Records for the deposition, and see this article for the interview with eight physicians:‘Sense of fear’: Ex-colleagues warn of DeSantis’ surgeon general pick Pamela Wible, M.D., has a website on physician suicide prevention that describes the tremendous stressors on today's doctors.Physician Suicide Archives | Pamela Wible Reports .

Some do, yes. As the other answers have noted, it’s common, probably >40% in primary care. I don’t. But then, I’ve done my best to “break the rules”, and so far I’ve had success in avoiding the pitfalls that destroy so many doctors’ love for the practice of medicine. Most of the dissatisfaction among doctors (like any other highly expert field) arises from being controlled by other forces (read more about this here). Read the other answers, especially User’s experience - control from insurance, hospital administrators, ACO’s, etc. etc. etc. This is (IMO) the core frustration in medicine - our expertise does not allow us autonomy; we are (as a profession) controlled by outside interests, and forever caught between the patient and the insurance companies. Concierge Medicine is the response to this intolerable circumstance. I’m proud to work for RiverRock Medical Clinic because we are not controlled by any third party. My work is simply between me and my patients. No insurance, no bean-counters, no administrators. I work as a hospitalist as well, but never as an employee. My contract is between myself and the CEO or the hospital group, 1 week at a time. If I am ever asked to do something that conflicts with my patient’s best interests (and it happens all the time), I just say no and there’s another hospital who would love to have me. And there is SO MUCH to love about medicine. I loved physics (still do), I loved philosophy (still do), I love chess, and poker, and helping people as a volunteer in college. But nothing compares to medicine. Medicine has all of that wrapped into the highest-stakes game of judgement calls outside of the military or the presidency. And it’s a game we play to help people. When we get it right, we prolong people’s lives, or at least improve the quality of their lives. Their LIVES!! It’s crazy-cool to have the opportunity to make an impact like that. Anyway, I’ve been lucky and blessed (and smart ;)). I love my job, and I think I always will. My heart goes out to those of my peers who have fallen into a (sometimes inescapable) trap between a rock and a hard place, and who experience the frustration of seeing their dream of helping patients turned into a nightmare of frustration or despair. Physicians should not have a high suicide rate, but we do, and that is a terribly, terribly sad comment on the state of our profession.
