response.answer_text: I have a friend who is a doctor. She said to me more than once that she regretted becoming a doctor. She got into med school riding on altruistic energy. She had never had a long lasting full time job prior to college because she was overachieving schoolasticly so med school might be possible. She would stop by my house on Fridays after I had gotten home from working a long week and find me collapsed and numb from exhaustion camped out on my couch mindlessly watching TV or napping. She occasionally made fun of me hinting that I was lazy (we are no longer close friends). Zoom forward to 3rd year med school for her and now she is interning and on rotations. Interning is a slave like experience, they are working huge hours and are treated often with cruelty by the superiors, and let's face it--- people generally do not become nicer when sick. Oh, so now its OK to crawl home after work and dive into pizza and your couch? After surviving internship she went into a private practice group as the newcomer that got the worst shifts, more frequent on-call shifts than her senior coworkers, and anytime someone wasn't taking their shift the new girl was expected to cover with no complaints. This was not the vision of being an altruistic God-like physician that she had planned on being. She had trouble not bullying the office staff and just like it is in ANY office, unkindness to secretaries and clerks will always come back and bite you in the ass. After a very bad week she came to me to cry on my shoulder, so frustrated and now regretting becoming a doctor. She had a mountain of school debt, was exhausted all the time and was living with shattered dreams. Kinda like everyone in middle class America. I really had to dig deep to find compassion for her.

Many U.S. doctors regret choosing to become doctors. recent surveys have shown that 30% to 40% of practicing physicians wouldn't choose to enter the medical profession if they were deciding on a career again[1][3][6] This quote helps capture a lot that sentiment: "I wouldn't do it again, and it has nothing to do with the money. I get too little respect from patients, physician colleagues, and administrators, despite good clinical judgment, hard work, and compassion for my patients. Working up patients in the ER these days involves shotguning multiple unnecessary tests (everybody gets a CT!) despite the fact that we know they don't need them, and being aware of the wastefulness of it all really sucks the love out of what you do. I feel like a pawn in a moneymaking game for hospital administrators. There are so many other ways I could have made my living and been more fulfilled. The sad part is we chose medicine because we thought it was worthwhile and noble, but from what I have seen in my short career, it is a charade."[1] U.S. doctors see themselves as lacking sufficient power and being told what to do by insurance companies and other forces. They spend a lot of time dealing with paperwork. U.S. doctors spend almost an hour on average each day, and $83,000 a year—four times their Canadian counterparts—dealing with the paperwork of insurance companies. Their office staffs spend more than seven hours a day. [1] They also have to deal with the threat of lawsuits and malpractice insurance. Salaries continue to be a multiple of house-hold income, despite the changes in the way medicine is practiced. In 1973,the median annual physician income was $45,000, and the median US house-hold income was $10,512[2] In 2014 house-hold income was about $51,000[4] and doctor salaries were considerably higher: In 2012, physicians practicing primary care received total median annual compensation of $220,942 and physicians practicing in medical specialties received total median annual compensation of $396,233.[5] Of course it’s worth mentioning that achieving these salaries requires a massive up-front investment in medical school that can result in significant debt, together with additional years of training in which the salaries can be well below this level. Salaries need to be forgone during the medical school years as well and may be well below those of other opportunities during the training years. [1] Why Doctors Are Sick of Their Profession[2] Page on nih.gov[3] Medscape: Medscape Access[4] Poverty rate 15%, median income $51,017[5] U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics[6] Medscape: Medscape Access

I’m essentially rehashing an earlier answer of mine to a very similar question. Ah, I see what your problem is. A evil witch has cast a spell on you. Confused? All right, I’ll explain. You see this?  That’s what has happened to you. You’ve fallen for the oldest con in the history of storytelling. And that is…  You believe in true love. I don’t mean your romantic true love. I mean your academic true love. You think that out there, there’s one body of knowledge that you are destined to make love to forever. It’s just that there isn’t. Most of the people I know who got into medical school alongside me were intelligent enough and social enough to excel at a whole range of professions. Many of them changed tracks too, after medical school. Some did an MBA and go into business. Some got a PhD and go into full-time research (like my mother). So it is not true that the course textbooks of one special profession are designed to spend one long night writhing in your arms in bed until the sheets are drenched in your sweat.Now, that was true in my case. But that was just that one time the power and water in the dorm were out all night, so I couldn’t shower after swimming in an over-chlorinated swimming pool, so went to bed with my pathology textbook. Look, whether you will love medical school or not is not some magical chemistry thing. It’s not about magic at all. It’s about love. And it’s about science. There are no two words more universally misunderstood than love and science. Nearly everyone thinks love and science are nouns. They’re not. They’re verbs. Science is a very specific series of actions we use to learn about something. Love is not a feeling. Infatuation is a feeling. Love is a series of actions. And if you put two and two together, you will get that the act of science is primarily an act of love. It involves watching inconspicuously from a corner, penning your observations down, then your thoughts, building, testing, failing, trying again, risking your reputation, and in the end, expanding your world. See? You can’t tell if I’m talking now about science or love. People often have it backwards, you know. They think that the feeling must come first, then the actions will follow. And that is true. But they don’t realize the opposite is true as well. If you act like you care about something, and start doings the things you’d do if you cared for it, you will find that, slowly but surely, you will begin to actually care for it. If you think your skill set matches, and you can afford the expenses, and you are granted entry, and you aren’t infatuated with anything else, take it! Seize your ‘Happily Ever After’ like all those Disney stories. But remember that the end of something is always the beginning of something else. Happily Ever After is just the beginning. If you don’t put in the kind of work every day that would make medical school love to have you, in the end, you won’t love the experience of medical school. You can never fully know if you will love the experience beforehand. There is no easy way. After all, the experience of medical school tends to be so objectively different (city, country, climate, cost, classmates) and subjectively different (mindset, sociability, mental health, physical health) for each person. So asking various people what it will be like is only partially helpful. The only real way to know will be to actually do it. The irony is that in order to get the most accurate answer possible, you will have to render the answer useless. So many of us assume that a person and a thing cannot become over time someone or something else entirely. Why do we assume that? People and things can and do change. Over half the doctors I know tend to regret joining the profession. When I probe, it really comes down to this: the rewards promised to them never materialized. What rewards? Oh, you know, easy money, minimum effort, social respect and of course, let’s not forget that last minor thing that sweetens every challenge: a hot girlfriend. You fell for that? “Buy two medical degrees, get one hot girlfriend free”? How old were you? 17? Oh,well, we know what that can be like. But you’re no longer 17, right? Grow up. As you age, your priorities and your passions change. Things that appeared important to you when you were 17 don’t when you’re 27. 27-yr old you will wake up in the morning with everything 17-yr old you wanted, and still count himself wanting. The reasons why you wanted to be a doctor, will often not be the reasons why you will continue to remain one. People often write so much about happiness, from a psychological and sociological and anthropological standpoint, that I think the reason so many people are still confused is because they’ve over-analyzed it. I think happiness is simpler than it seems. Mihaly Cziksentmihalyi, the author of FLOW, pinned down the traits to daily happiness: if the work is complex and challenging, relevant to reality, and varies from time to time, it will make you happy. I quote my shoes when I tell myself this at the start of each day: just do it. Give it all I’ve got, intelligently. If I put in the smart-hard-work toward my profession, if I defend it’s dignity, if I tell it what I really think, if I feed it my most original thoughts, if I will pay all these things toward my profession, each day, every day, then in the end, I will find, even though I’m not keeping score, that my profession has paid me back.

Why some? Many doctors regret their career choice because many of them get into medicine without understanding everything that comes with a career in medicine. Some find out midway that they didn’t sign up for what it demands. So the regret Some issues that students never considered when they entered medical school were (and I speak from an Indian perspective): 1. That medical education & training is a long and arduous journey. The reward is very far off and that not all reach the end of the tunnel to reap those rewards. There is a mismatch between their expectation and outcomes regarding their careers. Priorities can change in the time between a starry eyed 18 year old kid entering medical school and a 35 year old frustrated doctor. One of the popular jokes going around last year which though sounds funny but is unfortunately true. 12th Results are being released on May/june 2015. All those toppers who will begiving interviews that they are planning to enter medical field, this is your next 18 years: 2015 Feb - 12th Exam2015 May/june - 12th Results2015 July - Enter Medical College2016 August - I MBBS2018 Feb - II MBBS 2020 Feb - III or Final MBBS2020 March - Final MBBS Result2020 Apr to 2021 March -CRRI / Internship 2021 or 2022 - state Public Service Committion or MRB 2023 Feb or March - Posted in Primary Health Center2023 to 2026 - 3 Year Rural Service 2026 Feb - state PG2026 May to 2029 April - MD / MS 2030 June - DM / MCh Entrance 2030 August to 2033- August -DM MCh And When you are preparing for your final exam in 2033 May, you will be reading an interview by children born this year that entering Medical College is their dream. 2. That medical education has become very very expensive today, even for those who manage to get into medical school and residency through government subsidized undergraduate and post-graduate programs. The costs? Opportunity costs of 10+ years of nearly no income when compared to other STEM fieldsLiving costs and family commitments during medical school and residencyNo fair system to match qualified doctors to appropriate positions once they finish medical school or/and residencyIf someone spent the kind of money needed to get non-subsidized medical education, there’s no ethical means to recover that corpus working in a salaried job.High stress environments where doctors work in affects their family life and also puts them at risk for addictive behavior and suicide.3. That compensation at the end of their residency will not match those in the same age group who went to other fields. Many doctors feel disillusioned when they actually enter the job market. They have constantly been told by their parents and relatives that once they have got into medicine, their life is set. No one has prepared them for the reality that not every doctor has fairy-tale stories of high salaries and lavish lifestyle. Doctors either need to be from an elite background or be extremely skilled at generating revenue for hospitals to really enjoy a rich lifestyle. The fact that one’s skills or knowledge or even ethics is not readily converted to well paying jobs is heartbreaking for any conscientious doctor. 4. That there is a major mismatch between medical school slots and residency slots. There are 55,000 MBBS graduates passing out of medical schools in India every year while there are hardly about 5,000 government subsidized residency program slots among all specialities. Many are doing residencies in specialities they don’t like because they didn’t get what they wanted and didn’t want to risk getting into the residency exam rigmarole again- a success rate of 2–3% to actually get a rank in the All India Entrance test. Career options for those who don’t crack the residency entrances are very limited. I have spoken about it in detail here. Has the Indian medical system of Post graduation become a rat race? 5. That we are woefully short of mentors to guide the next generation of doctors. Typically the best training in India happens in government medical colleges- not necessarily because of brilliant teachers but because of the sheer number of patients in these hospitals.* The quality of teachers in medical colleges- both in government and private- has dropped drastically in the last couple of decades. This is due to indiscriminate increase in MBBS seats without any consideration for the quality of medical education provided. Hence the students and residents who graduate from such colleges are of lower quality than the previous generation. The rather insecure present faculty see their students as their competition and intentionally under-train them. So it takes the new doctors more time to get up to speed with the latest. Teaching and mentoring is never incentivised so no one makes a better effort. If you pay peanuts you will get monkeys. 6. That violence against doctors, vigilante justice and public shaming of doctors in news media/social media is becoming more common. The worst part is that in most cases it’s not even the doctor’s fault and many times the information given by the media is grossly wrong. While the irresponsible media can’t take back their words in today’s world of instant 24/7 news, the damage done to individual doctors’ careers is irreversible. 7. That breakdown in the Patient-Doctor trust is increasingly becoming more of a problem. This breakdown has resulted in less respect for doctors among patients, colleagues and other allied health professionals. Higher litigation has resulted in more defensive medicine and less empathetic patient care. 8. That poor quality infrastructure, facilities and poor maintenance of existing infrastructure in government hospitals is blatantly visible. Yet the government still tries to force all medical students to serve compulsory rural postings. Why do Indian doctors refuse to work in villages? 9. That the red tape in government and bureaucracy will make sure that people who have never ever visited a government hospital for treatment nor have an elementary idea about healthcare will get to decide how hospitals will be run, what expenditures to make and who should be hired. When substandard equipment and medicines supplied by the government coupled with unrealistic surgery targets to be “cost -effective” results in adverse outcomes for patients, the doctors are made scapegoats, arrested and put behind bars. Botched surgeries land docs in jail ; 2014 Chhattisgarh sterilisation deaths *I can attest however that there are still some very good teachers left in private and government medical colleges. I was just speaking of the general trend. Personally speaking, this post is not representative of my own experience with medicine but one from seeing medicine from close quarters. The above points I mentioned is not a rant since I do not regret my choice to do medicine and haven’t experienced disillusionment in medicine-YET! I probably beat many of the odds that I have mentioned in this post to reach where I am. Many others aren’t as lucky and I can empathize with their plight. The following article has found resonance among many Indian doctors and many have agreed with it’s message. Why I will never allow my child to become a Doctor in India ! The author, Dr. Roshan Radhakrishnan -an Anesthetist ends with this note: I have been conversing with a lot of doctors recently and the sound of disillusionment about the field has never been as loud as it is today. Even doctors of generations past and heads of departments acknowledge the shift, stating that they are happy that they are not starting off their careers in today’s India. One line which many of them said and one which I also agree with entirely is the basis of this article – “I will never allow my children to join this field.” There is also an email sitting in my inbox asking me to sign and share a petition demanding that applications for licensed guns be fast tracked for doctors. I have read it and placed a ‘star’ across the mail. I do not intend to sign it because I don’t advocate guns as a rule… I see children cry everyday when I bring an intravenous cannula near their tiny arms. I do not wish to have them worry about the gun in the doctor’s pocket too. But I empathize with the sorrow of the doctors who made the petition. And I know one day, I too may find myself revisiting this petition should a calamity befall me. As it is, hospitals have started employing bouncers now. I would love to hear from doctors here as well. Even if you disagree with my thoughts entirely, I do not mind. I just want to see how far the disillusionment lies and whether the “Hippocrates Oath” and “selfless service” tag are still as strong in your hearts today as it was the day you joined your medical college. Where do you think it is all going wrong in India?

Wow… thats a very good question and am so glad am getting a chance to speak my heart at this forum. We as doctors dont regret becoming doctors per say, but we regret the kind of life we lead because of our profession. To start with, by the time we graduate, our colleagues from other professions are already working and almost getting settled. Our struggle has just begun aftr our graduation bcoz the options aftr graduation are vry limited and esp wen u hav struggled thru ur graduation so mch, u dnt feel like going for smaller options. Aftr graduation comes the time when we start learning the practical approach of our profession. The theory and the practical world are vry vry difrent in medicine. It takes almost a year or two to get well versed with the application of all the fives year theory knowledge on your live patients. By the time all this is completed we are almost 25 to 27 yrs old. Normaly ppl like to get settled before getting married. But in our profession i dnt knw how many can say this. Either you get married late or give your burden along with your spouses burden to your parents again. And with the kind of culture we have, the second option implies to most of the cases. Aftr all this struggle it finally comes to your fate when you start with your private practice. If luck favors you, you flourish. But even that takes atleast 2 to 5 yrs smtims. Now the point here which appears in mind is that aftr struggling for 10–15 yrs what are we achieving. There are many better options available to achieve the same so called financial, mental or social success with much lesser struggle and most importantly mch less of time involved. These were the professional aspects. Now coming to the personal aspects. The one thing which i am sure ech and evry doctor will agree upon is that they dont hav a personal life at all. The wrk schedule is sch that we cannot attend any social gatherings be it birthday parties, weddings, anniversaries etc. Evn if v do luckily get an opportunity to attend, v r d last to rech once our consulting is over bcoz we cant afford to leave smone ill and attend sm hapy functions. People feel that we r behind money and thats y v dnt attend functions. But that is not true. It is vry difficult to leave smone suffering and go n njoy urself and dats one imp reasn y v chose to attend the sick rather then njoying ourself. Having said that, i would also like to say, that evn if v r staying to earn money what is the problem. V also hav a family to look aftr. Y r all the social gatherings done in d evening? Dat is bcoz ppl can finish off their work and attend the gathering. No one wants to miss on their work and no one will miss on their jobs and work to attend a social gathering until n unless sm vry close relative is involved. Our wrking schedule is sch that v hav to wrk late in d evenings wen evryones retrning frm their wrk so that v can attend them. If v start attending evening functions not nly will v suffer financialy, but the patient will suffer as well. Patients want a doctor who is available full time, but v end up paying a grt cost for it… Our phones are always ringing, be it home, clinic, school, office, between gatherings, movie theatres, day, night, and v r bound to answer them. Now most of ul can say that v can switch off or answer as per our convinience. But then ask youselves that if u call ur doctor in an emergency and if he doesnt answer ur call how will u feel. V think bout this and dats d nly reasn v answer all calls evn in d middle of the night. When i was single it was ok doing this, but today am married, i hav a yr old son who sleeps with me. When the phone rings in the night it not nly wakes me up but my small son as well. All these factors are nevr imagined by normal people, but am sure ech and every doctor must have gone thru dis at some point of their life. Last but not the least, its a very unthankful job which we do. We dont expect people thanking us for eveythng. We know its our job. But then there are people who are being thanked for the worst of works. And we as doctors inspite of few words of kindness get to hear how expensive our treatment is. But then they tend to forget dat it is that expensive treatment which makes u worth enjoying ur life or living your life in peace. Inspite of all these facts, i would still say that i love my profession, i dnt regret a bit…. But then it comes with a great cost to me and my family and that is what i regret. I dnt regret being a doctor. I am always proud to b a doctor. But if somone will ask me what i want my son to b, i will never give an option of being a doctor.

I once went out for a lunch buffet with an Indian doctor in Tennessee. I went to discuss some business related to practice management software. As we began to have our lunch, an young intern of his joined us. It was a big buffet. So, we had time to talk. We discussed his practice, about ICD-9 to ICD-10 transition and his general state of affairs. He had been in business for more than a decade. So, he was quite well set. Coming from India, he talked about how he came to pursue this line of occupation rather than the Engineering line. It was not surprising considering that most of the Indians growing in the 80s and 90s mostly had the doctor (MBBS) or engineer (BTech) educations to choose from. However, as we began to talk about the money part of his business, I sensed that things were not going that well as he would have wanted or as much as he had expected when he chose this profession. It was not because he was losing customers or that there was competition. He talked about how the health insurance industry was making it hard for him to get paid. You see in the US, the healthcare insurance companies get into the act once a patient visits a doctor. They go through the due diligence procedures (Coding, billing, claims and whole 9 yards) before the doctors and hospitals would get paid. The doctor talked about how delayed payments were upsetting his small practice. He grumbled about how it was no longer lucrative to be in this line of occupation. What’s more, he wouldn’t encourage his own children to pursue it. I was surprised that he was that frank about it in front of his intern. I think the hard times were speaking, but what really amazed me was what the doctor did next at the lunch table. As the waiter placed one more plate of the Indian Naan on the table, the doctor quickly covered it in the paper napkin and swiftly / secretly pushed it in his suitcase.  I was sad to see that happen, but more sorry to see him do it in front of his intern. As I drove home after the lunch, I thought it was not this particular doctor’s problem. It could more likely be the problem with the US industry as a whole which must have forced him to regret his career choice. Edit 1: After posting my answer and seeing some of the comments here, I think I need to explain a few things: The doctor clearly mentioned the problem with insurance regulations and how they were impacting his practice. That was the crux of his situation. It had nothing to do with his own personal motivation(s) to stay put or get out of this line of occupation. I have seen other answers where they have talked about how the industry is getting stifled by regulations which are beyond the control of a small practice.When I said “lucrative”, I did not mean to say “huge amount of money” or “insanely large amounts of profit”. There is no implication of “greed”. The point is that when you take up a career, you research how stable you will be in that line. When you study to be a doctor, the general thinking is that you are going to be reasonably well-off. I think, in comparison with other career choices, a doctor’s earnings should be fairly good enough for parents to send their children to a medical school.The example I gave of the naan could well be wrong. I could have been wrong in connecting the doctor’s frustrations with pushing the naan into his suitcase. And hey, who is to say if the doctor just liked a naan to take home. And what’s more (and everyone knows), how awesomely tasty naans are.

Yes. Some Doctors do regret becoming a doctor. However, this statement is true for most professions. In each and every profession, there always will be people who regret becoming what they are. Having said this, the answer to WHY this happens is also multifactorial. A lot of people choose their profession based on the likes and dislikes of their parents, the glamour associated with the profession, peer pressure at the time of choosing a speciality etc etc.. Also, Medical profession is really a unique profession in the sense that it is much more demanding mentally and emotionally than generally recognized. This combined with absence of proper group practice norms in India, makes it even more difficult. Running a private practice (even moderately successful one ) demands 24 X 7 involvement. And by 24 X 7 , I mean 24 X 7 And if you have picked up this profession just to satisfy your dad / mom , then later on it becomes really frustrating. And I guess that is why a lot of doctors do not want their children to enter medicine. Also, the unchecked involvement of the Corporate Healthcare groups have reduced the sanctity of this profession. Personally, I feel this is the biggest factor leading to the disillusionment of a lot of doctors. Since Corporate hospitals are established to generate profit, this becomes the goal of practice of most of the corporate physicians. Although it is easy for some to get used to the corporate medicine ways, but a large majority of the doctors remain attached to the corporate hospitals mainly because of lack of opportunity. The only other thing for a lot of people is to go solo, which may not even be an option in certain specialities. However, becoming a doctor is in itself a fulfilling experience, and I doubt any other profession can match it. And yes, we do need a lot more good doctors in our country. I would not discourage my children from becoming doctors if they choose so. But yes, I will be honest with them regarding the drawbacks of this profession.

Like with ANY profession there are going to be those who regret their choice. The LONG LONG process though, does serve as a sieve of sorts. The first filter is having to take science courses in undergrad, be amongst the top of your class, and take the MCAT. This removes a large percentage of people that wish to become physicians. You follow that with four years of medical school, where there is a small but significant attrition rate. Follow that with 3–7 years of residency training from which people DO leave though in smaller numbers than in prior steps. And then you’ve ARRIVED! You are an attending physician, respected by your peers, paid handsomely by the hospital, bringing value to society….and then you realize you have to fight insurance companies to obtain imaging, hospital administration to get new equipment, explain to your wife and kids that you’re going to miss the birthday party AGAIN, your student loans and tax bracket mean you’re going to be comfortable but not jet setting around the world, some unscrupulous people will try to sue you, you can’t spend as much time as you would like with each patient because the finance department wants to see more “volume” from you…. It’s not for everyone. For those that took the long journey and then left, I wish you the best of luck and there are some days that I envy you.

I would not choose to be a doctor if I had it to do over again. I would go into astrophysics and enjoy astronomy or possibly become a professor. Saving lives is a strong draw, and every kid dreams of being that person who rescues others. Or maybe they don’t, but I did. The full on sacrifice of an important decade of your life (your 20s) and the enormous debt (paid off by age 40) could be forgiven if medicine was what it SHOULD be. When you are smart enough to do anything in the world, and when you are an ultra conscientious high achiever, it is very very difficult to see your world controlled by people who are in every way intellectually and morally inferior. I know that sounds horribly arrogant, but if you have ever been bossed around and threatened by a bean counter who is obsessed with his own power, you will know exactly what I am talking about. Politicians who don’t know what DNA stands for, who couldn’t read a statistical analysis if their life depended on it, are controlling the entire system based on a lust for power, control, and money. Doctors are so intensely obligated to their work that they do not have the time or the emotional energy to fight back. The AMA folk are officious suck ups who kowtow to the powers that be. The credentialing organizations are unelected powerhouses with the authority to charge you mandatory fees and determine your right to practice. It is really getting ugly. And as for me, having had personal health problems, the job itself is very inflexible. There are few to no options for part time hours.

Yes, some have told me. They are overwhelmed with paperwork (charting), and basically the quota that they have to meet (they have to see so many patients per day). The administrator sets a goal for everyone to follow – and when something goes wrong, it is the doctors that are responsible for the malpractice. Basically you have 15, 20 minutes to see each patient and to document the case and you go to the next one. You cannot second-guess yourself – some doctors privately told me that they order a lot of tests to cover themselves. Then there are phone messages that you have to personally answer, or assigned to a nurse (your nurse) to return the calls. He also have to review the lab results, etc. They do not give you the time (an empty slot in the schedule) to do that – you do it between patients, or at the end of the day, or at lunch hour. For example as a doctor, the patient comes in with back pain – there could be so many things wrong. It could be something simple as muscle pain (from lifting improperly), to bladder infection/kidney infection, to other, much more serious conditions. While I understand that taking a good history (“how did this happen - does it sting when you urinate - did you lift something heavy - does the pain go down the leg - do you see blood in the urine - etc. etc”) may give you a clear clue about what this patient may have, there are tests that must be done to find out and basically to cover your ass - if you end up in court, that is. I am a nurse – at the end of the day, I am able to walk right out of the clinic and the doctors stay for another hour, or two, or more, to finish their work. Money doesn't mean much (although they do get a lot) but they have very little personal time to enjoy themselves. Some are better than others with time management – but that is another story.

Ya I regret but that is because of my faulty decisions and not because of medical field . Here is my story…. 8th July 2010, The day I wish i could go back and change my decision, will tell about it later. May 2010, results of Class 10th board were declared, got CGPA 8.8 ( ours was first batch to face this all new grading system of CBSE ), and so whats next typical middle class society thinking - aapke bhai ne science leli and that too with Maths and Biology. Story doesnt end here, Life ki bakchodi abhi baaki hai mere dost :’). Since I belong to a family where highest educated person is my father (8th paas), so u can imagine about my family education background. So after few days of class 11th people started talking about different coaching institutes for various entrance exams (AIEEE, IIT, AIPMT). I heard for the very first time in my life about AIPMT,IIT etc. So I asked one of my friend about it asked him what I should do ? He said since you have taken biology so its better to take AIPMT coaching, as I was new to all these things and did not have any exposure from family side, so blindly accepted the advice and took admission in one of the best AIPMT coaching institute and paid 102000 fees for 2 years course. 8th July 2010, the day when I took admission in coaching. After few months I realised that this field is not for me, but thought that it might be due to increased study pressure I am having such thoughts. Again in my 12th class I started having same thoughts of dislike for bio and likes for engineering and this time I was more confident about my insights, and this time my teachers and batchmates started telling me to opt for engineering as I would do good in this field and leave coaching for medical as it was not too late, also I was quite good in maths but I ignored it all. But deep inside I knew they were right and my likes for engineering and dislikes for medical started ballooning, but the same middle class mentality kept me from taking any decision as I already paid huge amount of fees for medical coaching. So whats next ? I started feeling guilty and that guilt kept on increasing, as I could not find someone to guide me at this point of time. Nov-Dec 2011 The application forms for various entrance exams were available, so just to reduce the guilt I filled AIEEE ( Engineering enterance ) form along with other medical exams form. Results of entrance exams (2012) AIPMT = Qualified but rank not good for admission AIIMS = Didnt qualified BHU = Qualified in pre, but didnt gave mains DPMT = Qualified and got seat in UCMS DU Now the most important result, AIEEE = Qualified with good rank and to the surprise my result was 2nd best in my school, among all who took engineering coachings. But at the end of the day it was of no use : ( Fast Forward Completed my MBBS, without any backs and supple ; ) Gave PG medical exam, got an average rank and took MD Pathology ( MAMC DU). Currently in 2nd year residency. And even till today for the last 10 years I am living with the same guilt, why I didnt chose engineering :( . But as it is said its never too late to start new , So i am doing something new which I will post soon. Learnings 1 = Always listen to your heart, it will always take you to the right place. 2= Never ever in your life hesitate to step back, its okay, its life, it might be pulling you backward just to give you a head start for your new journey. 3 = Do what you love, money doesnt matter at the end of the day. 4 = Talk to yourself what you wants to do and follow what your heart says. 5 = Never hesitate to ask someone for any help. Thanks

I know a lot of colleagues who profess that regret. Whether or not all of them really mean it is another thing. I do feel at least 3 of these colleagues mean it. But 2 of those individuals went into the profession due to family expectations, so that’s unsurprising. Personally, I don’t regret having become a doctor. But it just so happens that What I Thought I Was Getting Into and What I Actually Got Into fell pretty close to each other. So if I had to try to generalize the “average” case of MD regret, it’s probably about expectations vs. outcome: some expect more money in the profession, for example, or more prestige. Others expect it to be a constant procession of helping others, when the reality is only about 30% helping others and 70% figuring out that “help” only goes so far. People can feel regret for a million reasons. I even know 1 person who told me he’d never have chosen to be a doctor if he knew how little respect doctors get in society nowadays. Have to admit that sounded like a stupid reason to regret going into medicine… but that’s just me. I don’t feel like asking society to respect me more than the plumber just because he can’t do an appendectomy. Considering how many times my parents break faucets in their house too, I wouldn’t be surprised if my family respected him more, actually. They definitely call him more than me!

I'm not neither a doctor nor planning to be one. But I would like to share my own story on this. It is common for some doctors to regret their career. I'm from Iran. Yep, a country which is under severe sanctions since 1979 revolution and the end of 2500 years of Persian monarchy. Medicine is a hot topic in Iran. The new generation of Iranians see it as a path to free money and lavish lifestyle. They see being a doctor as someone who has a lot of prestige and drives his Maserati in Tehran's upscale neighborhoods to pick-up some hot girls and go party with them all night. Guess what? As soon as the graduate from high school they have to take konkour which is the Iranian University Entrance Exam. Oh, all of a sudden after they fail it the 1st time they realize to get accepted in Konkour they need to study. So they start studying. Next year comes and they fail again. They see that they have no interest/chance in Medicine so they change their major to humanities and arts or business. They end up there. Some people pass the exam and go for medicine. After the 1st year they realize med school isn't for them and they drop out. They see it as a hard topic. But others keep going until they become a doctor after 7.5 years of studying. Then they are send to spend 1 to 3 years in a rural city to help fellow Iranians. It all adds up to 10.5 if you are lucky. Then after that they have to put their whole lives on their career. They have to be there 24/7 and help people. Trust me it is not an easy job.

It’s a very complex question though seemingly simple enough. To answer it in a straight forward manner,” Not some but majority doctors regret becoming one”. So you now know “how common”too! Why? That needs a lot of elaborating. I am a surgeon admitted to medical school in 1984 ( not many private medical colleges then) so only merit mattered as far as getting admitted to a medical school was concerned . I was so happy and elated then,but for all the wrong reasons. I enjoyed the attention and praise I was getting from relatives and acquaintances. I used to enjoy the appreciative stares from unknown bypassers as I donned my apron and started for my med school everyday. I also enjoyed overhearing conversations where relatives would mention my parents that within less than a decade this boy would be driving a posh car and living in a deluxe house. I was almost a celebrity in my colony and my family as I was the first from both the circles to get admitted to a medical school. All wrong reasons as you can see and I can admit for getting into a medical school. After years of deliberations I can tell you it was for all wrong reasons that I chose this profession. Where was the empathy, the urge to save lives,the desire to alleviate the suffering of fellow humans ? Not taken into consideration to be honest. Frankly speaking I wasn’t alone. Every student getting admitted to med school has these factors into consideration. Now getting back to the point, as a doctor or surgeon you have to take decisions. Decisions which literally make a life and death difference . What factors do I consider in those crucial decision making seconds. Is it worth taking this risk? Are the relatives hostile? What are the eventualities that this decision might boomerang (though that being the clinically correct decision). How much will I be paid for this particular adventure considering what is at stake? While doing so the helpless man on the bed gets lesser marks than a rouge/ bully relative of his. I hope you get the point. Most of us in this profession are there basically for wrong reasons. But we are intelligent enough and in some cases manipulative enough to blame the society for all the bads. You must be hearing a lot about doctors not getting enough PPEs while treating Covid patients. Have you ever, in last 70 or so years heard a soldier complaining about going to the frontline without a bulletproof vest? No, because he is driven enough and motivated enough to fight for his motherland. Unless we have people with same desire and determination entering medical field there are going to be regrets!!

Yes. I am a doctor (MBBS, UK) who regretted his career choice. I always wanted to be a scientist/engineer/inventor, and was persuaded when I was young that medicine is a good route to being a scientist. Medicine in the UK is a very vocational degree, and a doctor’s job is very, very hard, and very, very long hours - not leaving me a lot of time for science/fun. After 6 years of medical school and 3.5 years of working as a doctor, I quit clinical medicine and moved to a full-time PhD. In retrospect, I wish I had studied engineering or chemistry, because the job market would be a lot more interesting and varied for me (and pay better!) with those degrees. Also, I might have done one of those degree first, whilst I matured enough to consider medicine more carefully. Also, I would be more scientifically/mathematically knowledgeable/skilled if I had studied a ‘pure’ science first, rather than studying medicine so young. Medicine is also tough psychologically. Mainly because the demands of the profession, and of patients/society, on doctors are constantly increasing, but (in the UK), there are fewer doctors, and pay is stagnant. Medicine is a career where you are expected to make NO mistakes, which is humanly impossible, and the toll of that is great on doctors’ mental health. Politicians do not respect doctors; neither do the media. The public, thankfully, still trust and appreciate doctors, but that relationship is constantly tested by changing relationships with money/internet self-diagnosis/social media. I still love the NHS and do anything I can to support it with my time. But it’s a tough, tough job - only really for those who love it! — Cheers! Tom —

I think it is more common than people would think, I’m a medical student in my last year of med school, and even though I wouldn’t go as far as to say that I regret studying medicine, there are moments when I just think “What the hell did I got myself into”. We sometimes even joke about it, someday someone asked “what would you say to yourself 7 years in the past?” and most of us would say “DON’T GET INTO THAT HELL CALLED MEDICAL SCHOOL!!”. Some of my other friends (non medical students) already graduated from college and are working in nice jobs, some are married, some are married and with children…, living a pretty normal life for people my age (well maybe not the children….), and here I am doing my internships in an hospital, at 3am, after a crazy day thinking “What am I doing here!?”. But don’t get me wrong, even though it’s crazy and hard I don’t regret studying medicine, I know that I could have chosen a easier career, and maybe I would have a nice job by now, and a completely different life. But I also know that if I had done so, I would also be regretting not having studied medicine.

As people say, life gives you lemons, make lemonaide. Becoming a doctor is not one decision you make while in the bathroom in senior high. It’s a long series of decisions. I almost burnt out as early as Internship. 36 hour shifts can push your tolerance for work. So I decided to pursue Pathology. I love it so far! Pathology turned out to be surprisingly interesting, and while you can get quite busy, you are the master of your own time. No need for late night trips to the ER, no early morning rounds. There are many choices to fit your lifestyle and interests in Medicine. Like office work? Take up hospital administration or work for an HMO. Some clinical specialties offer this as well, including Rehab Med, Radiology, and Developmental Pedia. Like to write? Be an editor or contibutor to health related publications. Want to teach? Research? There’s something for you. Even in Law enforcement (Forensic Pathology). And if, at any point in your career, you are still not happy, just go do another fellowship. Or do an MBA. Or take up Law. Because of this, I believe people who regret all their lives that they took up Medicine are not very common.

When studying at medical school, I was taught when answering multiple choice questions that any question (medically) that contains the word “never” is false and that any question that contains the word “ever” is true. So - do some doctors regret their choice? Yes. I don’t. People choose to be a doctor for many different reasons - intellectual challenge (House), money (not a good reason on its own but here in the UK doctors do reasonably well financially - if money is your sole reason, there are lots of better choices), flexibility over the duration of a career, wanting to “help” people (research has been done on why doctors and nurses feel the need to “help”) and many other individual reasons, I’m sure. The population as a whole still rates doctors as the profession they trust most - but remember that compared to politicians and bankers they may feel the competition isn’t too strong. However, in the UK, a doctor is the most prolific serial killer ever (Harold Shipman) so please trust only when indicated. I am incredibly lucky - I can genuinely try to improve people’s lives. Sometimes I achieve this. Sometimes I don’t. But I know that every day in my working life will be interesting, challenging and different from every single other day in my occupational existence. So I don’t think I will ever regret the decision. This answer is not a substitute for professional medical advice.

I do not regret at all. But if I am asked, would you like to do other things beside being a doctor, I will definitely say yes. I have so many things that interest me. Languages, designs, art, music, sports… And I managed to do some of those during my crazy schedule at the college and hospital. I took French course. I made sketches of landscape n faces at night until early in the morning. I watched football games that started at 2 am, that caused me missed my first and second hour of lecture a few times. I even switched one of my intern slots with a friend to attend a singing competition ( I was also playing the guitar while singing, haha..). I mean, I don't want to lose my real life just because I have a degree to catch. I never intended to get the highest score, but of course I had my target. Finishing it the fastest that I could. And yeah, I was one of the fastest 6 graduates of my batch. The point is, I am the master of myself. I set my bar, I made my choices, I did my strategies. Which subjects I will put my attention more on. How to get along well with people surround you. What time to study, when to rest and have fun. I do want to have a balance life. The same thing happened when I got my acceptance letter to continue my study, just a few days before my wedding. I really had to bite my lips so hard and go with my decision. Now I am raising my daughters. They are 11 and 12. Never missed any single of their important moments. Literally spending my whole day with them. I am not active at a clinic or hospital, but I got plenty of family and friends who calls me to consult, and I'm doing my doctor job pro bono. Do I regret being a doctor? Never. Once you are a doctor, forever you are a doctor. I am planning to continue my study and back to the field in six years. When both of my daughters go to college, when they won't need me that much at home. I am happy with my life. And hopefully making others happy, too with the path that I chose.

I don’t really know in other developed countries. I just want to add another examples for “regret becoming doctors” I hope this is a topic about Medical Doctor. In Vietnam, which is where i live, many students compete each other harshly to get a high score in the National High School Exam. The results will be used to evaluate and choose outstanding students to the Med school. Many of them though after 6 years of study( in Vietnam, students apply to Med school directly from High school through a National test that was mentioned above) that they will have nearly everything: respect from their families and relatives, high salary, an important position in society, etc. However, the Med school, like anywhere else in the world, has a very stressful study schedule. Vietnamese Med students have to learn 9 modules in one semester, do some internship duties in the hospital at midnight, then go back to school in the morning for lectures, and have tests of modules at the end of the modules. Also after graduated, they have to study 2-3 years more in order to get a Medical Qualification for paticipating in a position as a real physician. Although a long and hard time of study, the salary isn't the same like in developed nations. They are not well-paid, and Doctors have to diagnose nearly 200 patients in public hospitals. They are also hit violently by patients who do not feel “welcome” and some punks or jerks. Many students or even experienced physicians want to quit the job and move to another field. They don't feel secured and have good income when they just graduated. And that's why doctors in my country regret for what they’ve chosen.

there are many reasons one can regret career decisions, and in my impression this can be distilled to the situation being regrettable. some at random: - prolonged high stress situations with unnecessary additional stress added by greedy politicians, patients, and third party payers. Too few non monetary rewards, such as time off, evenings off, minutes to think, minutes to enjoy time with relatives, minutes to yourself, minutes in the grocery store unrecognized. Too few vacations. Too many administrators asking for too many patients for employed slaves. Who wants money if there is no time to spend it. The real problem is our culture of complaint - a culture with the philosophy of “critical theory” cooked in, where political correctness has stifled the simple humor if simple souls sharing a problem to convert horror into joy. Instead we expect the powerful to solve everything and accept no responsibility ourselves, infantilized by our political parties. Physicians have the rare privilege of watching people they care about slowly destroy themselves. Physicians get to watch patients blame everything but themselves without lifting a finger to prevent the avoidable. In combat, soldiers see their comrades die painfully, but never does a soldier watch his ally leave cover and grab a bag of potato chips to stroll through a mine field. Through this field of bodies and severed limbs lies a ray of hope. I live between the lines of the page hoping for my next fix. A hopeless case at the last minute turns. I live a day longer.

I don’t regret it, but would probably try to become an enrolled actuary now if I had a choice(I’m an Electrical Engineer) because it appears that in becoming an actuary one enters a profession that is arguably a meritocracy: After obtaining a degree in accounting there is a series of tests that when passed advances one in the profession. I don’t have first hand knowledge of this. So much of the insurance “industry” involves estimation of risk I would say if you can’t beat them join them. Back in the day I was involved in the creation of an HMO. The ability to estimate risk in a population was crucial if the business was to survive. I could “do the math” (with help) and understood the medical side too(I’m an Internist, pulmonologist, critical care etc.). I enjoyed internship and residency and could at least hope I was “useful” after all the training. But it was very tiring, as was active practice. I never got enough sleep. If I chose medicine the second time around I would try to become a dermatologist! No hospital, no night, weekend or holiday work. Too late now…

From the UK: I do not regret my choice but I do resent what has happened to it. The job that I joined to do, trained to do, hugely enjoyed doing and which will always need doing - interacting with, examining, advising, treating and caring for those who are or who believe themselves to be ill and especially having regard to the physical, psychological and social dimensions of a patient's presentation - is great. The problems arise from the interference of others - especially politicians - who have little or no knowledge of the realities of medicine, are burdened with prejudices and are pursuing agendas alien to caring. The commercialisation of care is particularly malign for a variety of reasons. The intrusion of industrial style management is actively harmful to patients. A medical career, when taken as a vocation rather than as a route to riches, is more a state of mind and mode of living than a job. It has high and low points but is socially useful and constructive. Burnout is fairly common as is disillusionment when ones proper role is corrupted by external forces. Being a doctor when you do not have the vocation could be a special kind of purgatory.

I don't regret being a doctor, but I won't let my kid become one.  Yep, I said it.My father is a doctor, and so was my grandfather.My grandfather was the best doctor in the town, and it was in that era maybe, that doctors used to get the respect they deserve.So did my Dad. He has been the finest doctor of the place I grew up in, and there's hardly anyone who took treatment from him as a kid, and doesn't remember him. As soon as I got in. I have been tangled in the issues of limited seats, reservations, undeserving students getting privileges, corruption and paid seats, patients treating doctors as shit, awful laws and bonds by government to spend life in rural areas without any facility or security on meager salary, and cut throat competition to get into master's after completing graduation, where again you face reservation, and rich brats. It's demoralizing. And the examination pattern is bizzare whose pattern changes every year. Like it's some kind of joke. It's a joke to become a doctor in India. I won't let that happen to my kid.My dad sees me and thinks the same. I can understand his plight. I hope history doesn't repeat itself. Edit/Disclaimer : It has been pointed out by a gentleman that my answer is coming out more as a demotivation for people who want to pursue a career in medicine.I'm sorry, if it did. I, by no means, wish people to not take up medicine. We are in real need of good doctors in our country. My anger is not towards the subject, or the profession. I love my job. My frustration is towards the system, which has created nuisance. But, as rightly pointed out by that guy, nuisance and absurdity prevails everywhere.:)

I gave my son (then 4) a cheap stethoscope as a toy. When I mentioned this in a room full of junior doctors the reaction couldn’t have been more negative if I’d said I’d let him try hard drugs. They were all - perhaps 6 of them - unanimously appalled to an extent that surprised me. I think it’s fair to say that the overwhelming majority of junior doctors I meet in the UK regret their decision to study medicine to a greater or lesser extent. I’m happier than average. I’m going to stop here and state that this is within the UK. In other countries things may be different. For example, from the USA I read a lot about the trials and tribulations of dealing with insurance companies which is one thing that we thankfully don’t have to deal with here. In New Zealand, doctors have greater medicolegal protection from the consequences of medical errors. I’m presuming you’re asking the question for a purpose - perhaps to decide whether or not to study medicine? What it means to be a doctor clearly differs from one country to another. I think it’s also going to change greatly in the future, as information technology changes the way we work.

I am actually writing a paper on this topic! A common occurrence within doctors is something called physician burnout. Typically, some of the symptoms involve exhaustion, cynicism, and the general sense that what they are doing doesn’t matter. One major cause of this are bureaucratic tasks and the intricate record keeping that comes with it. This can make physicians feel more like paper pushers than doctors, which can be incredibly frustrating, especially considering the intensive training they underwent. Another cause is simply specialty. Some specialties are a lot more physically and emotionally demanding of the physicians. For example, consider being a neurosurgeon, where a slight movement could cause crippling damage versus specializing in public health/preventative medicine where they might focus on developing legislation over clinical care. Another contributing factor is their home lives. Physicians that have work-home conflicts are highly likely to experience burnout, as well as physicians with high amounts of debt, no children, or no significant other. Hope this helps!

I do not regret becoming a physician. I deeply regret how unaware I was of how it profoundly changes you forever. I regret how I didnt grasp the expected and silent hypocrisy required to practice medicine in America's for profit system heavily influenced by prodits, politics and law. I regret how rhe demands of practicing hospital based medicine impacted my family in ways very nearly impossible to mitigate. I so not regret how I treated patients both as their advocate and their doctor. I am embarrassed and to a great extent, outraged at how the US political system cultivates and weaponizes inequalities on medical care. “Inequalities” is a euphemism for tolerating the widespread ability to marginalize and alienate another person in a manner directly causing harms to that person that their family. After 30 years of 80+ hours a week delivering, teaching and leading bedside medical care I decided to leave medicine. And I do not miss it for medicine has become almost wholly about liability shifting and not care sharing.

"I have no interest in medicine".. that says it all my friend.. a sure fire way to regret choosing medicine at a later stage of your life.. you may have heard how tough and difficult it is to become a doctor.. right from getting a good rank in aipmt or the state medical entrance exam to passing every subject in the mbbs curriculum which can make all your 12th look like a library reading session.. The pressure that one faces at every year will be really huge.. and at the end of it all there is one year of gruelling internship which will shake your very core.. extreme poverty and illness and you will realise that sometimes you can do very little to save them.. and after that comes the biggest hurdle you will face.. post graduate entrance exams.. studying all the subjects again and remembering every small detail in them..finally more often than not you will do a course you end up with rather than your own choice.. and after all this you face the real world.. I don't have to say how difficult that is..  So a doctor knows how difficult it is to become one.. now comes the most important thing that matters.. perspective.. what do you want in life.. what do you consider as happiness and satisfaction.. that differs in every individual.. some doctors don't want their kids to undergo the same difficulties but whereas there are plenty who feel it's worth it and their kids can make it..  Being a doctor there are some moments which you simply cannot gain in any other profession like witnessing child birth, looking at the smile and gratitude of a person who walks cos u saved his life or limb and the respect of society in general (even in current times).. all this and u get paid for it too:-) know that there are pluses and minuses in every profession.. what makes u the see pluses and ignore the minuses is your own attitude and interest.. that's what I call perspective.. so if u have that go for medicine.. if not and instead u have a fixed idea of say earning plenty of money or command lots of respect (mind you it can still come) then u will end up regretting ur choice..

This is not my personal story but of the professors where I received my undergraduate degree. My pathophysiology was an M.D. who went to Oxford. He did nothing but spend a year studying for his MCAT. He got a perfect score and went to medical school. Now he’s just an associate professor and plays golf on his free time while his wife is a director of a local hospital. My A&P professor was a Vet and her husband owned a lab. He donated all his equipment to the university to become a microbiology professor. My biochemistry professor got tired of researching the same protein for two years so he decided to go into teaching. My cell biology professor, in her early 30’s has three PhD’s, and it’s also her first mortgage. I would think 100’s of time before going into medicine because of the time, money, physical, and mental investment to this profession. You’ll also lose much of your youth, then later time for your family. When I was a medical interpreter, I asked an ER doctor how many hours he work a day. He said, “I do 48 hour shifts.”

Well, the article you cited answers your question.  The poll surveyed 24,216 doctors and health care professionals in 25 medical specialties and found that declining pay and high levels of student loan debt have doctors increasingly dissatisfied with their professions. Substantial pay gaps between areas of medicine also have doctors upset, while male physicians are paid 40 percent more than females across all specialities.  The ones thinking about retirement don't know if the money will be there for them because of declining revenue fears and investment losses over the past few years. They fear that the government and insurers will increasingly tell them how to practice. Younger doctors are afraid that they won't be able to pay off medical school debt as fast as they expected.  In a sentiment expressed by many of the 3200 physicians who commented on our survey, one doctor said, "ACO arrangements are a conflict of interest. Administrators, not physicians, will decide what's allowed. It would also spell the end of solo or small group practices."  "More and more, physicians feel that someone is telling them how to treat patients," said Bohannon. "They worry that the guidelines are promulgated to reduce overall costs rather than put patients first. Doctors feel that they have to give up more autonomy and they resent being told how to exercise their medical judgment."   "Too many doctors have little idea or time to devote to the cost of care," said Aburmishan. "They often don't do their own billing or collections so they don't know what each insurer pays. They are so busy with paperwork and seeing more patients that they don't devote much time to overall cost issues."   Bohannon agrees. "As medicine moves more and more to an employed model, most physicians feel that their responsibility is to treat the patient's clinical problem. The cost issue is secondary. Most doctors don't believe that it's their job to focus on that."

In mainland of china，most of my classmates regret  their choice of studying medical.we need 11 years to get our doctor degree,form bachelor,master then doctor.But what we learn during our studying is doing experiments,writing articles,we have little free and time to learn how to cure a patient. Medical resources are uneven distributed. It is hard for us to find a job. Even if we are luckily enough to enter into a big hospital,we will not become economic independence in 4-6 years.The Physician-patient social contradiction is big. Every day,one  needs to see more than 100 out-patients,with low registration fee about 1.5 RMB(about 0.25 dollar) to 15 RMB(3 dollar). But the price of drugs are high,which exacerbates the Physician-patient contradiction.whereas the price of drugs are made by the government.There was a report in The Lancet ：Chinese doctors are under threat http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(10)61315-3/fulltext

Personally I do not regret it but medicine has changed since I graduated from medical school. I went to MIT with the purpose of going to medical school and becoming an orthopedic surgeon. When I practiced patients were generally thankful and there was a good doctor patient relationship. Now we have networks which are steeply discounted, bureaucracy, and limits to what test and medications we can prescribe (or endless paperwork). I advised my children not to go in (both of their parents are physicians). Both went in CS/EE at MIT and are making more that an average physician. I agree that we do need physicians and more of them, however if the student does not have the drive I wouldn’t recommend it.

The statistics are there; the incidence of stress among doctors is nearly 28% compared to 18% in other professions. Various surveys had indicated that 30–50% of doctors in various parts of the world regret the choice of their career. And it seems the icidence is almost the same irrespective where you are in the World. I expect the percentage will be even higher in the future. The factors can be summarised in the following: Financial pressure: doctors take more time to graduate, further years of training after they fully qualify they usually have high level of dept.Family/social pressure: doctors work long hours and always have to juggle their commitments around. Trying to achieve work-life balance is exteremly challenging.Career (Professional) pressure: finishing medical school doesnot mean finish to studying and exams. In doctors life it means adding clinical work to studying/exams along with the other responsibilities.Regulations & litigations: practicing medicine is getting extremely complex with various regulatory mechanisms which at times hinder doctors from providing the care. Along with the increased litigation, incresed percentage of doctors practice defensive medicine.Erosion to medical professionalism: Medicine is enterprise of trust. The combination of the above factors and others eroded doctor-patient relationship, a siginificant percentage are finding it very difficult to fully empathise withtheir patients when they have significant levels of stress.

My husband is a very successful doctor, he has his own clinic where he does unique procedures, he has developed and patented his own drug, teaches med residents in one of the best universities in Canada and works in emergency to keep practising those skills. Sounds like a perfect scenario. Except my husband is a very talented man. He wanted to be a computer scientist.But it was unpopular in his country so he became a doctor but if he proceeded, he would've created an app by the age of 20 and 15 years later he would be travelling the world and getting steady profits from his invention stress free. Currently, his jib is very stressful and oftentimes patients are ungrateful and outright rude. On top of that, you have to deal with government billing, which is very complicated because government prefers to pay you less and you have to prove why you should be paid more.

Yes. I know an anaesthetist who regrets becoming a Dr or certainly at least his specialty. He makes a very good living earning over $400,000 a year, but finds his job incredibly boring as he just puts the patient to sleep, then just monitors the patient while the surgeon does the operation. And 99% of operations go fine at least as far as anaesthesia is concerned. So really all he does is sit there with nothing to do except glance at a monitor every now and then, but mostly I gather the monitor will sound a warning if the patients vital signs deteriorate. He does a lot of serious long operations where he almost dies of boredom.

I enjoyed being a doctor in many ways but possibly would not do it again. There is an expectation that you go the extra mile (stay late, see extras, cover others who are off sick etc) - & this is not compensated at all. I was fine with that except employers take it for granted & use it to cover the gaps caused by underfunding. Politicians endlessly talk up expectation & don’t resource it & are quick to try and blame health care workers for shortcomings in the service. Everyone should see their GP within 48 hours & faster if urgent they say - I am fine with that if they resource it but they don’t. They seem to spend their time finding ways to increase workload & telling us to work smarter & use “slack in the system”. I have often wondered how it was safe to keep going on next to no sleep while “on call” (ie working as normal in out of hours time) & being expected to perform at full pace the next day. Oh well I am retired now, have fond memories of most patients - but no time for my previous employers.

So many docs regret their choice of profession due to the society .My dad who is a doc says that I can choose any other profession than  doctor .It is because people don't recognize their true form and people don't appreciate their hard work .No respect is given in the society . They are killed if they cannot treat a person but not even thanked if they save a life . The other reason is that you have to strive hard to become a doc . When you are in grade11 and 12 , you have to study hard ( day and night ) to score in the exams .When you start your college , you have to attend all the classes (if you don't ,you won't understand the whole concept ) ,therefore , you have to strive hard in your college days .When you start working ,you will have to work day and night .You spend your whole life with no fun if you become a doc and at last ,people kill you if you could not save a life which has half of its life gone . I would say that if you are willing to strive hard before and after becoming a doc and if you will be devoted to your job forever , last but not the least , if you prefer becoming a doc than fun , you can become a doc . All the best for being successful .

I do regret it, mostly for the astronomical load of anxiety it has given me my whole working life. if I make a mistake, someone could die. if I struggle with a procedure, someone could die. if equipment fails, someone could die. if a junior I am supervising makes a mistake, someone could die. if I fail to keep people moving through my department, someone could die. if I send someone home and they don't come back when they get worse, they could die. plus there are things that are not dying, but that are nearly as bad. then there is the knowledge that I can do everything right, have a bad outcome, get sued and lose. Not a great recipe for sleeping well at night. i could have lived a much happier life without this.

It depends the motive behind your study. There are (& majority) those who study for fame & money & if they don't get mostly money, they regret saying they wish they didn't waste time studying the discipline & they are the ''doctors'' who didn't go to school to study & understand but pleas the examiner. Last year i was invited to an emergency medicine meeting by a friend of mine who heads emergency unit (ambulances & fire-engines) of a private company & when we were queuing for lunch, a medic behind me asked his friend whether really healthcare was at it's best, the friend (whom i later got to know was a pediatrician) responded '' i don't care, what i need is money''. When the meeting was over i was told later by my friend that most medics attended the meeting, not to deliberate on how emergency medicine can be made effective to the public but coz there was sitting allowances.

This looks like a yes/no question, but it isn't. We all have our "I didn't sign up for this crap" moments, some more than others. Direct care, retaining autonomy and cutting out insurers, is a great way to minimize the heartache, but if you've noticed, the general political speech these days is in exactly the opposite direction in the US. We may all wind up being disgruntled employees (well, not me, necessarily, since I've reached 65 years of age).Anybody who's delivered a baby, or performed any of a million other life-affirming tasks, though, has to be an optimist at some level. We may dislike some of our patients. We certainly find it easy to disagree with insurers and administrators. But few of us give up on medicine itself. We sometimes just need reminding, and a little reason for hope.

I know Few Of the The Doctor Professionals Who are practicing On the General basis in EmergencyDepartments .. A doctors Usually miss There Teens like 20’s to 27’s jus studying on the book without much enjoyment and much Family functions and other things . So it's another small issues ..
