Hii there. It's true that some doctors regret choosing their profession,the reasons to the question 'why' is Mutlifactorial. But the main reasons are less Money paid for putting in HardWork, Sacrificing Family time, friends, personal space and Sheer Stress associated with this profession. In the end all doctors are human beings too . They too have some emotions. Doctors too have little dreams of spending time with their family, children, travel and enjoy their lives but it gets really hard when all of these gets snatched right in front of your eyes but doctors don't have a single complaint as for them Patients health and safety is Foremost priority and everything comes next. It's common in developing countries like India because of the pressure, harsh working environments, less pay and nowadays manhandling has become a recent part of it. A doctors profession is a DIVINE GIFT.. it's bestowed on you through your HardWork, Dedication but at the same time you have to Sacrifice the most valuable things in your life..Time, Family and Friends!

Conditions are almost the same in all developing countries. Selected few of highly intelligent students get the chance to become doctors. They spend their entire youth, parents' money + hopes and their own health to be qualified as doctors. By the time they start searching for a job, their colleagues in other professions are settled and raising their families. Beginning of their carrier and beginning of family-life run parallel and competing with each other. If this was not enough, low paying and highly stressful working conditions shatter all the dreams. Doctors caring for others health, work in unhealthy conditions. Fear of litigation, business pressures, government regulations and some ungrateful patients; all make life painful. In India, even patients assault doctors at times and police cannot protect. Passion of serving the sick and saving life is the only motivator against so many denominators. Very few lucky ones get good working conditions and all the doctors are not very rich.  For most, it is point of no return. In developing countries, there are hardly any options for a middle aged person. Is it sufficient answer to your question?

Yes, sometimes doctors regret their decision to enter medicine, we would not be human if we didn’t. Sometimes we regret the time medicine takes us away from our families. Sometimes we are disappointed that medicine has not turned out the way we expected- adoring patients who trust and respect us and accept everything we tell them as truth. Instead we encounter patients who are demanding, rude, non-compliant and resist our efforts to help them. Most of all, we regret that we are not able to help every patient that comes to us -many get worse instead of better, and eventually, they all die. But- knowing that we are a select few who have been lucky enough to practice a profession dedicated to treating the sick, relieving pain, and comforting the dying, makes the sacrifices worthwhile. And for that we have no regret.

The average person goes through about 5 changes of career in a lifetime. And doctors are no different. They are human, and have the same life struggles as everyone else. Being a physician is a great privilege, but also a lot of hard work and continuous study. it can easily affect a relationship. Divorce is common. And sometimes people just want a change. Changing specialties in medicine is actually fairly common. If one is not committed to being a doctor, s/he will end up having problems. Medicine is not about the money, but about helping people. Sometimes the money is good, but not always. There are easier professions or careers that make more money.

To answer this question I would like to recall a research " severity of stress in Pakistani medical student" by Haider Ghazanfar and et. all and the result is quiet surprising where around 14% of the respondent wished to quit their medical study and even the incidence of stress in various category is surprisingly high. The result is somewhat similar in similar research. So it's really hard and needs metal preparedness and proper counselling during the medical study. Anxiety disorders . Panic attacks , insomnia etc are quite common during the exam hour . And so it's really hectic during the medical students' life . Many become addicted to drugs, Marijuana, alcohol or smoking cigarette during their medical life. The answer to question lies . It's quiet common thought among medical student and it varies accordingly to their timeframe of their life. Busy study hours , dedications, no free time to hangout with friends and even family, lesser personal time for the family , burden of work and study matter , exams and longer duration of study are the frustrating points for medical students when their contemporary pals are enjoying their life. But, but, but Once after the medical students' life is gone , it's the professional life that adds colors to life once again. Higher level of reputation compared to the same level of earning, seminars, medical society, pretty good salary, and of course the degree that's get paid higher social status lures youngster for pursuing medical career. Never to forget the attachment of patient care and wish for the social works and volunteerism cannot be skipped off.

If you are naturally good at Organic Chemistry and need not to recite then medical science is right for you. Like I say how to convert Phenol to Acetylsalicylic acid easily.  I read Organic Chemistry 15 years ago. That benzene ring remain inside the head, knocking the hydrogen from -OH and adding the side chain plus one carboxyl group works fine. Second step involves Kolbe Schmitt reaction. We remember Anatomy in that way like remembering the street maps. None needs a GPS navigation to go towards own house from grocery market.  That bland biology has less to do with Medical Science's subjects. You need really good in calculus, trigonometry, physics etc. Because these are towards higher math. Diagnosis and surgical pre-op planing is higher math.   Why so many doctors regret their choice of profession? Human has the bad habit of blaming & cursing. Most expect that money will fall automatically from the sky, none will disturb, all will be uneventful.  Indian Engineers, specially the S/W engineers also curse on Quora.  It is true that patients becoming angry towards the doctors, but behind that anger there are valid reasons. Most importantly, those blaming doctors never mention the advantages of near free treatment of own and the family members.  Reading is huge in Law too, work is abnormally higher in Law.

Yes some doctors regret their choice of profession and there are various reasons for this. Quite commonly, some doctors chose medicine over their passions for other subjects-these doctors will always regret coming into medicine. Some folks were too young when they chose to commit to medicine only to realise later in life its not really what they want to do. Where you practise medicine and your choice of specialty can also lead to regrets. For me, its all about perspectives. Medicine is not a perfect career but there is enough for everyone if you make your choice carefully. I am extremely grateful for the opportunities Ive enjoyed as a result of becoming a doctor.

I DON'T REGRET- because 1)I have been very passionate about medical science. 2)I love to be empathetic and to have a small contribution towards helping out people in need 3)It gives me immense satisfaction,when a patient says THANK YOU,for getting treated. 4)It makes me feel proud of myself I DO REGRET-because 1) Doctors are being overworked and worked under extreme stress, getting compromised with their own health 2) Doctors are being threatened,harassed by uneducated political goons, bureaucrats 3) doctors are getting beaten up by patient's attenders inspite of trying maximum to save a patient (Indian people gets so emotional that they always consider doctors are guilty unless proved to be innocent) 4)when i ended up spending my 20s(10yrs so far) in studying,trying to pass out of tough exams to qualify to practice! 5)when you get to know our govt (India),invests less than 2% of GDP in healthcare! 6)when I realized that people show more faith and belief in their neighbors,relatives,Babas and celebrities rather than a doctor,when it comes to treatment part.

When one opts for medicine, they are not opting for a career option that is like any other. At a time when their peers are settling in their respective careers, they are consumed in thick medical books, preparing for their grueling exams. When their peers are going the family way, they are busy working the 18-hour shift. And when their peers are cheerily talking about their retirement plans, they are still finding their ground in their profession. Despite all the hurdles, the medical profession is still considered as the noblest profession by the young generation, parents of the medical doctors and the people. Government is taking several measures to address all the issues. The numbers of seats in various medical schools are being increased and many new medical colleges are also being planned to set up. It is rightly said by Alfred Lord Tennyson “Hope smiles from the threshold of the year to come, Whispering ‘it will be happier’…”. Although most of the doctors regret being in this profession( Specially in India).The most common reason behind this kind of mentality is that they are not getting their due both financially and socially ( They spend major part of their life in studying and lengthy duty hours) .They are supposed to serve the society anytime and everywhere irrespective of the fact that they also come across day to day problems a common man faces.Doctors also need space for their family and personal life.As far as I am concerned I love my profession to the core. I suppose I can't get interested in any subject other than science/ medical science.Moreover saving someone's life is the greatest satisfaction of the life.I would like to pursue this profession again as a surgeon.

Becoming a doctor may seem a dream job, but it turns out those already practicing don’t always agree. Yes, some doctors regret becoming doctors.
